user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_update_last_activity_:
```c
void
MHD_update_last_activity_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (0 == connection->connection_timeout_ms)
    return;  /* Skip update of activity for connections
               without timeout timer. */
  if (connection->suspended)
    return;  /* no activity on suspended connections */

  connection->last_activity = MHD_monotonic_msec_counter ();
  if (MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon))
    return; /* each connection has personal timeout */

  if (connection->connection_timeout_ms != daemon->connection_timeout_ms)
    return; /* custom timeout, no need to move it in "normal" DLL */
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
  /* move connection to head of timeout list (by remove + add operation) */
  XDLL_remove (daemon->normal_timeout_head,
               daemon->normal_timeout_tail,
               connection);
  XDLL_insert (daemon->normal_timeout_head,
               daemon->normal_timeout_tail,
               connection);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions were found in the provided code fragment. The snippet only uses standard C constructs: function definition, pointer accesses, comparisons, assignments, return statements, preprocessor conditionals (#if defined / #endif), and calls to functions or macros. I specifically checked for common compiler/vendor extensions that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2, including but not limited to: __attribute__ or __declspec, __builtin_* identifiers, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), inline assembly (__asm__), nested functions, GNU or MSVC-specific keywords, and other documented compiler extensions. The macro and function names that end with underscores (for example MHD_update_last_activity_, MHD_mutex_lock_chk_, XDLL_remove) are ordinary identifiers and not compiler extensions. Therefore there are no suspicious fragments requiring further investigation under Rule 1.2.
